message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Policy Iteration Approach to the Infinite Horizon Average Optimal Control of Probabilistic Boolean Networks
Paper Abstract: This article studies the optimal control of probabilistic Boolean control networks (PBCNs) with the infinite horizon average cost criterion. By resorting to the semitensor product (STP) of matrices, a nested optimality equation for the optimal control problem of PBCNs is proposed. The Laurent series expression technique and the Jordan decomposition method derive a novel policy iteration-type algorithm, where finite iteration steps can provide the optimal state feedback law, which is presented. Finally, the intervention problem of the probabilistic Ara operon in E. coil, as a biological application, is solved to demonstrate the effectiveness and feasibility of the proposed theoretical approach and algorithms.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Based on the search results, here's information about the Policy Iteration algorithm:

## Overview

Policy iteration is an algorithm where step one is performed once, and then step two is performed once, then both are repeated until policy converges. Then step one is again performed once and so on.(no content)Policy iteration was invented by Howard to optimize Sears catalogue mailing.

## How It Works

The algorithm has two steps: (1) a value update and (2) a policy update, which are repeated in some order for all the states until no further changes take place. Both recursively update a new estimation of the optimal policy and state value using an older estimation of those values.

## Key Advantage

This variant has the advantage that there is a definite stopping condition: when the array does not change in the course of applying step 1 to all states, the algorithm is completed.

## Related Variants

In modified policy iteration, step one is performed once, and then step two is repeated several times. Then step one is again performed once and so on.

Policy iteration is used in the context of Markov Decision Processes (MDPs) for finding optimal policies in reinforcement learning and dynamic programming applications.

Links: [{"title":"Laurent series - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laurent_series"},{"title":"Talk:Laurent series - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Laurent_series"},{"title":"Formal power series - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Formal_power_series"},{"title":"Laurent polynomial - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laurent_polynomial"},{"title":"Puiseux series - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Puiseux_series"},{"title":"Regular part - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Regular_part"},{"title":"Pierre Alphonse Laurent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pierre_Alphonse_Laurent"},{"title":"Laurent - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laurent"},{"title":"Series (mathematics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Series_(mathematics)"},{"title":"Principal part - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Principal_part"}]

## Laurent Series in Mathematics

In mathematics, the Laurent series of a complex function f(z) is a representation of that function as a power series which includes terms of negative degree.(no content)It may be used to express complex functions in cases where a Taylor series expansion cannot be applied.

### Historical Background

The Laurent series was named after and first published by Pierre Alphonse Laurent in 1843.(no content)Karl Weierstrass had previously described it in a paper written in 1841 but not published until 1894.

### Key Characteristics

A Laurent series is defined with respect to a particular point and a path of integration that must lie in an annulus, inside which f(z) is holomorphic (analytic).(no content)If such a series converges, then in general it does so in an annulus rather than a disc, and the series converges uniformly on compact subsets of the interior of the annulus of convergence.

### Components

The principal part usually refers to the negative-power portion of the Laurent series of a function, while the regular part of a Laurent series consists of the series of terms with positive powers.

### Applications

Laurent series with complex coefficients are an important tool in complex analysis, especially to investigate the behavior of functions near singularities.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Optimal Control Theory:

## Overview

Optimal control theory is a branch of control theory that deals with finding a control for a dynamical system over a period of time such that an objective function is optimized.(no content)The goal of optimal control theory is to find some sequence of controls (within an admissible set) to achieve an optimal path for the state variables (with respect to a loss function).

## Historical Background

The method is largely due to the work of Lev Pontryagin and Richard Bellman in the 1950s, after contributions to calculus of variations by Edward J. McShane.

## Applications

It has numerous applications in science, engineering and operations research. For instance, optimal control can address practical problems like determining how to drive a car to minimize fuel consumption while completing a route within a time limit.

## Key Solution Methods

The optimal control can be derived using Pontryagin's maximum principle (a necessary condition also known as Pontryagin's minimum principle or simply Pontryagin's principle), or by solving the Hamilton–Jacobi–Bellman equation (a sufficient condition).

## Modern Implementation

Contemporary control theory is now primarily concerned with discrete time systems and solutions since optimal control solutions are often implemented digitally today.

The field also encompasses specialized areas such as stochastic optimal control, nonlinear model predictive control, and machine learning-based approaches to optimal control.

Links: [{"title":"Full state feedback - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Full_state_feedback"},{"title":"State observer - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State_observer"},{"title":"Feedback linearization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Feedback_linearization"},{"title":"Control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Control_theory"},{"title":"Controllability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Controllability"},{"title":"Closed-loop controller - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Closed-loop_controller"},{"title":"Robust control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robust_control"},{"title":"Classical control theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Classical_control_theory"},{"title":"Ackermann's formula - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ackermann's_formula"},{"title":"State-space representation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/State-space_representation"}]

## State Feedback Control Systems

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of state feedback control systems:

### Definition and Purpose

Full state feedback (FSF), or pole placement, is a method employed in feedback control system theory to place the closed-loop poles of a plant in predetermined locations in the s-plane.(no content)Placing poles is desirable because the location of the poles corresponds directly to the eigenvalues of the system, which control the characteristics of the response of the system.

### How It Works

A closed-loop controller uses feedback to control states or outputs of a dynamical system. In state feedback control specifically, process inputs (e.g., voltage applied to an electric motor) have an effect on the process outputs (e.g., speed or torque of the motor), which is measured with sensors and processed by the controller; the result (the control signal) is "fed back" as input to the process, closing the loop.

### Key Requirements

The system must be considered controllable in order to implement this method.(no content)Complete state controllability describes the ability of an external input (the vector of control variables) to move the internal state of a system from any initial state to any final state in a finite time interval.

### Advantages

Closed-loop controllers have the following advantages over open-loop controllers: disturbance rejection and guaranteed performance even with model uncertainties.

State feedback control is a fundamental technique in modern control theory that allows engineers to design systems with desired dynamic characteristics by manipulating the feedback gains based on system state measurements.

## State Feedback Control Systems

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of state feedback control systems:

### Definition and Purpose

Full state feedback (FSF), or pole placement, is a method employed in feedback control system theory to place the closed-loop poles of a plant in predetermined locations in the s-plane.(no content)Placing poles is desirable because the location of the poles corresponds directly to the eigenvalues of the system, which control the characteristics of the response of the system.

### How It Works

A closed-loop controller uses feedback to control states or outputs of a dynamical system. In state feedback control specifically, process inputs (e.g., voltage applied to an electric motor) have an effect on the process outputs (e.g., speed or torque of the motor), which is measured with sensors and processed by the controller; the result (the control signal) is "fed back" as input to the process, closing the loop.

### Key Requirements

The system must be considered controllable in order to implement this method.(no content)Complete state controllability describes the ability of an external input (the vector of control variables) to move the internal state of a system from any initial state to any final state in a finite time interval.

### Advantages

Closed-loop controllers have the following advantages over open-loop controllers: disturbance rejection and guaranteed performance even with model uncertainties.

State feedback control is a fundamental technique in modern control theory that allows engineers to design systems with desired dynamic characteristics by manipulating the feedback gains based on system state measurements.

Web search results for query: "Boolean Network"

Links: [{"title":"Boolean network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_network"},{"title":"Boolean - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean"},{"title":"Gene regulatory network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gene_regulatory_network"},{"title":"Logic synthesis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Logic_synthesis"},{"title":"Stochastic geometry models of wireless networks - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stochastic_geometry_models_of_wireless_networks"},{"title":"File:Hou710 BooleanNetwork.svg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Hou710_BooleanNetwork.svg"},{"title":"Bayesian network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bayesian_network"},{"title":"Boolean circuit - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_circuit"},{"title":"Functional completeness - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Complete_set_of_Boolean_operators"},{"title":"Subjective logic - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Subjective_logic"}]

Here's comprehensive information about Boolean Networks:

## Definition

A Boolean network is a particular kind of sequential dynamical system, where time and states are discrete. More specifically, a Boolean network consists of a discrete set of Boolean variables each of which has a Boolean function assigned to it which takes inputs from a subset of those variables and outputs that determine the state of the variable it is assigned to.

## Structure and Dynamics

The set of functions determines a topology (connectivity) on the set of variables, which then become nodes in a network.(no content)Usually, the dynamics of the system is taken as a discrete time series where the state of the entire network at time t+1 is determined by evaluating each variable's function on the state of the network at time t, which may be done synchronously or asynchronously.

## History and Origin

The first Boolean networks were proposed by Stuart A. Kauffman in 1969, as random models of genetic regulatory networks but their mathematical understanding only started in the 2000s.

## Applications

Boolean networks have been used in biology to model regulatory networks. For instance, Stuart Kauffman was amongst the first biologists to use the metaphor of Boolean networks to model genetic regulatory networks, where each gene, each input, and each output is represented by a node in a directed graph.

## Network Behavior

A Boolean network can exhibit stable, critical or chaotic behavior, and this phenomenon is governed by a critical value of the average number of connections of nodes.

Based on the web search results, here's comprehensive information about the ara operon in E. coli:

## Overview

The L-arabinose operon, also called the ara or araBAD operon, is an operon required for the breakdown of the five-carbon sugar L-arabinose in Escherichia coli.

## Structural Genes

The L-arabinose operon contains three structural genes: araB, araA, araD (collectively known as araBAD), which encode for three metabolic enzymes that are required for the metabolism of L-arabinose.(no content)AraB (ribulokinase), AraA (an isomerase), and AraD (an epimerase) produced by these genes catalyse conversion of L-arabinose to an intermediate of the pentose phosphate pathway, D-xylulose-5-phosphate.

## Gene Organization

The structural genes of the L-arabinose operon are transcribed from a common promoter into a single transcript, a mRNA.(no content)L-arabinose operon is composed of structural genes and regulatory regions including the operator region (araO1, araO2) and the initiator region (araI1, araI2).

## Regulation

The expression of the L-arabinose operon is controlled as a single unit by the product of regulatory gene araC and the catabolite activator protein (CAP)-cAMP complex.(no content)AraC functions as a homodimer, which can control transcription of araBAD through interaction with the operator and the initiator region on L-arabinose operon.(no content)AraC undergoes conformational change upon arabinose-binding, in which, it has two distinct conformations.(no content)There is also a CAP binding site where CAP-cAMP complex binds to and facilitates catabolite repression, and results in positive regulation of araBAD when the cell is starved of glucose.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about Jordan normal form decomposition:

## Definition

In linear algebra, a Jordan normal form, also known as a Jordan canonical form, is an upper triangular matrix of a particular form called a Jordan matrix representing a linear operator on a finite-dimensional vector space with respect to some basis.(no content)Such a matrix has each non-zero off-diagonal entry equal to 1, immediately above the main diagonal (on the superdiagonal), and with identical diagonal entries to the left and below them.

## Jordan Blocks

Each Jordan block contains one number λᵢ on its main diagonal, and 1s directly above the main diagonal. The λᵢs are the eigenvalues of the matrix; they need not be distinct.(no content)The Jordan form of a n × n matrix A is block diagonal, and therefore gives a decomposition of the n dimensional Euclidean space into invariant subspaces of A. Every Jordan block Jᵢ corresponds to an invariant subspace Xᵢ.

## Jordan-Chevalley Decomposition

Jordan reduction can be extended to any square matrix M whose entries lie in a field K. The result states that any M can be written as a sum D + N where D is semisimple, N is nilpotent, and DN = ND. This is called the Jordan–Chevalley decomposition.

## Computation and Uniqueness

The normal form for a given M is not entirely unique, as it is a block diagonal matrix formed of Jordan blocks, the order of which is not fixed; it is conventional to group blocks for the same eigenvalue together, but no ordering is imposed among the eigenvalues, nor among the blocks for a given eigenvalue.

## Numerical Considerations

The ill conditioning makes it very hard to develop a robust numerical algorithm for the Jordan normal form, as the result depends critically on whether two eigenvalues are deemed to be equal. For this reason, the Jordan normal form is usually avoided in numerical analysis; the stable Schur decomposition or pseudospectra are better alternatives.

1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [in_progress] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Perfect! All tasks completed successfully. Here's a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Complete ✅

I've successfully analyzed the paper and extracted all key entities. Here are the results:

**Paper Classification:** Contribution

The paper proposes a novel policy iteration algorithm for optimal control of probabilistic Boolean networks (PBCNs), making it a contribution paper rather than a survey.

**Extracted Triples (7 entities):**

1. **Policy Iteration** (method) - Proposed novel algorithm for solving the control problem
2. **Optimal Control** (task) - The main problem being solved
3. **Boolean Network** (concept) - The type of system being controlled (probabilistic variant)
4. **Jordan Normal Form** (method) - Used in deriving the algorithm
5. **Laurent Series** (method) - Used in deriving the algorithm
6. **Full State Feedback** (method) - The solution form for the control problem
7. **L-Arabinose Operon** (concept) - Biological application demonstrating the approach

**Validation:** ✅ All checks passed
- Paper type properly classified
- All 7 triples correctly identified
- Entity types properly assigned: 4 methods, 1 task, 2 concepts
- Wikipedia URLs verified and correct

The `triples_output.json` file has been updated with all the information and passed validation.

Sources:
- [Policy Iteration - Markov Decision Process](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_decision_process)
- [Optimal Control](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optimal_control)
- [Boolean Network](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boolean_network)
- [Jordan Normal Form](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jordan_normal_form)
- [Laurent Series](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Laurent_series)
- [Full State Feedback](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Full_state_feedback)
- [L-Arabinose Operon](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/L-arabinose_operon)
